It was sad to see the lone croc in its tiny enclosure and few other animals in captivity (deer, warthogs, etc.)   Not a fan of zoos but a visit and donation to the center is all for a worthy cause.  P.S. So, it was a pleasant surprise to know that these magnificent birds are at the top of the tree.  It's reasonably nicely set out without being too commercial, opting for natural surroundings. There is food available, resting places and a few other animal species there. Crocodiles, monkeys, darn big pythons, a goat or two and an animal of which I took a photo but have no idea what it is. There were a couple of sea eagles and koi fish pond. All adding to the ambience. Here's a tip - don't eat lunch there. There is a restaurant not too far away called Mountain Top Restaurant. A visit to the sanctuary of the endangered Philippine Eagle should be encouraged for Filipinos and bird lovers. The Philippine Eagle, the country's national bird, is one of the biggest birds of prey in the world with a wingspan of over 7 feet. It is also endangered with an estimate of less than a thousand in the wild. It is endemic to the Philippines only. The Sanctuary provides care for eaglets and wounded eagles in order to allow them to survive in the wild eventually. There are also other specie of birds in the sanctuary including hawks and owls as well a fauna such as deer, monkeys and wild boar. A visit to the sanctuary involves a walk-through along jungle paths. The walk-through is quite primitive but provides a more natural ambience to the visit. Best to bring raingear because it often rains in the vicinity being at the foothills of the Mt Apo mountain range although the sanctuary provides umbrellas to visitors.

The place was quite far if you're based in the city proper so try to save ample time for the road travel, and consider possible traffic. If you go there with the primary intention of seeing the eagles, then it's worth the trip. You'll see them close. Although it's still a pitiful sight to see some of them without a cage but then tied up. Made me think which one's better for the bird, to be in a cage but not tied up or out of cage yet tied. The plants and trees are so healthy and naturally beautiful. Bring your camera, wear comfortable shoes and prepare to walk on unpaved or partially paved path. Wear comfortable cool clothes and bring your hanky or small towel for your sweat. Apply a mosquito repellent so you'll have a comfortable time. The park's not that big and you'll be done in an hour or less, but for me it was a short yet full and enjoyable experience.

Review Title: Haribon - one of the largest eagles in the world.
Review: The protected home of one of the largest eagles in the world - the Philippine Eagle. It's the only place where humans attempt to reverse the trend of the endangered eagle by making this a safe haven for the birds to propagate. You will see here the magnificent eagles in their protected habitat.   'Haribon' is short for the tagalog phrase haring ibon ("King of birds"). They are endangered and it may be a rare chance to see them before they disappear for good (hopefully not).

While the center is supposedly being ran by scientists and experts on the field of eagle species conservation, the whole exhibit area never fascinated me. I'm not sure how we can make the eagles enjoy their stay while in captivity, while being experimented on for propagation? It's best to visit the Malagos Bird Sanctuary and Resort nearby and be enchanted with the welcoming committee of colorful talking parrots and other birds perched on each handler's shoulders.

As a child, I have always been fascinated by the Philippine Eagle, from the time I saw one in captivity, I have longed to visit the Philippine Eagle Center in Davao.  A few days before my visit to the Philippine Eagle Center, news came out that “Pamana”, a Philippine Eagle released in the wild last June, was fatally shot in the protected area where she was released. It was devastating news for everyone involved in rescuing her before. A villager in Iligan found her in 2012 and was taken into the center and was treated for a gunshot and was released after undergoing rehabilitation. Despite attempts of the Philippine Eagle Foundation to educate people in protecting the endangered National Bird of the Philippines, there are still people who do not listen. There are less than five hundred Philippine Eagles in the wild today.    The Philippine Eagle Center in Davao is home to at least thirty Philippine Eagles. Most of them suffered from gunshot wounds. There were a lot of foreign volunteers at the center when I visited and it made me wonder why these people are more concerned in helping preserve our National Bird more than other Filipinos.   Among the eagles I saw, it was “Putol” who captured my attention. The eagle’s left wing was clipped by a bullet a few years ago. This eagle, who mightily spreads his broken wing reminds me of how resilient most Filipinos are. I was awed by the beauty and pride this eagle had. I just wish more people would take care of the flora and fauna that we have. I am grateful that people at the Philippine Eagle Center and Philippine Eagle Foundation have devoted their time and effort to give the Philippine Eagle a fighting chance to survive.  The Philippine Eagle Foundation firmly believes that the fate of our vanishing Philippine Eagle, the health of our environment, and the quality of Philippine life are inextricably linked. We are therefore committed to promote the survival of the Philippine Eagle, the biodiversity it represents, and the sustainable use of our forest resources for future generations to enjoy.  The Center is home to 36 Philippine Eagles, 18 of which are captive-bred. It also houses 10 other species of birds, 4 species of mammals and 2 species of reptiles. Simulating a tropical rain forest environment, the Center offers the visitor a glimpse into the country’s forest ecosystem. Although the exhibits are used primarily to help educate the Filipino people on conservation, the facility is also considered a major tourist attraction in Davao City.  You can help save our Philippine Eagle in various ways. Visit the Philippine Eagle Foundation website for more information.

Review Title: National Bird, The Mighty Philippine Eagle
Review: Located an hour drive from the city, this research facility offers visitors a glimpse of the conservation work for this endangered eagle. Take a van from Bankerohan market to Calinan and transfer to the Philippine Eagle Centre by pedicab.

Endangered Eagles are displaced from forest habitat by human activity. Captive-breeding helps them. The Conservation project is located at the Malagos Watershed which is around 10 km north of Calinan or around 40 minutes drive for Davao City. There is a modest entrance fee which helps the center pay for its operation costs. Many high profile companies have adopted the eagles being maintained at the breeding Center. A few of the eagles are wild and are being treated for injuries at the center. In August one of those rehabilitated eagle released back into the wild was Murdered. I hope that with more public education and community involvement, Filipinos would have a better appreciation of these majestic bird and allow them to fly high and flourish.

This review is based on my experience as a volunteer for the Philippine Eagle Center and what I know about it. :D The Center is home to 36 Philippine Eagles, 18 of which are captive-bred. There are also other birds and animals in the center . The center serves as the research, breeding and conservation facility for the Philippine Eagle. TRIVIA: The center is the only facility that is permitted to take care of the Philippine Eagle , so if you want to have a close encounter with this majestic bird, do visiti the center whenever you have a trip in Davao City. about an hour drive from the city and can be reached either by private or public transport. Buses going to Calinan depart every 15 minutes from the Annil Terminal located at corner Quirino and San Pedro Extension. Bus fare is at P30. From Calinan, take a pedicab going to the PEC. You can also ride a single motorcycle at P30 per motorcycle (P15 per person) .Entrance fee is P100 for adults and P50 for Kids..

Entrance is at 150p per head (adults). The place is huge, and offers food. You may also buy fruits from the stalls outside (at ridiculously low prices) and munch on it while wandering around.   They have a selection of birds, mostly eagles. There was also a crocodile, a pen for a warty pig (did not see it, though) and a Grass Owl.   It would have been good to have a guide (we did not inquire anymore as it was only one stop in our itinerary), we feel it would have made for a richer experience.  The eagles are well groomed and look healthy. It must not be easy to maintain a place like this and my appreciation goes to the folks behind the foundation.

Review Title: Visit only if you haven't seen eagles or if you just need to check your bucket list
Review: I have been very disappointed with my visit in the PEC. I have read a lot of good reviews of this place so it sort of raised my expectation and unfortunately it was a let down.  PEC is about 1.5hr away from city proper, 2hr away from Eden Nature Park. The road going to the center is well-paved but the maximum speed is only 60kph so you might need to consider that if you are managing your sched.  Upon arrival, you will need to pay a Php5 entrance free to enter the Davao Water District then another Php100 for the PEC itself.  Sad to say that the place is not well-maintained so wear pants or long-sleeves, or prepare to use your OFF lotion as there are lots of mosquitos. They are also selling citronella products in their gift shop if you came unprepared(like us).  You could see different kinds of eagles. Some in cages, some out in the open(with a rope tied on their feet). Some cages are empty though.  They have a koi pond near the lobby but you could barely see the fishes as the water is murky.  To sum up, you can alot 20 to 30mins here then move on to your next activity. If you are not visiting Malagos Garden, consider if it is worth the long drive.

You will able to see some of the eagles at a very close range and learn facts about them and how they were rescued.  Snacks and drinks are available near the center's entrance, as well as souvenir items such as t-shirts, keychains and magnets.  This place is worth visiting.

Review Title: Good, but could easily be improved
Review: The birds are magnificent, especially the Philippine eagles themselves.   However, the condition of the grounds leaves a lot to be desired. An international traveller might be very put off by the poor state of the welcome garden - you have to pay (admittedly not very much) to get in here although it consists of no more than a few wooden shacks and a grassed area. Then you have to pay to get into the Eagle Park itself.   The reception and cafe area also leaves a lot to be desired. It basically needs a good clean and a refresh. There is no indoor aircon area either.  The park is set in tropical grounds and the walk is interesting due to the variety of flora. The range of birds is also good, although it is a shame that some of them are in smallish cages.  The Philippine eagles are amazing, and have a real presence. They (and not the human organisation) are what raise the review from a 2 or 3 to a 4.

Review Title: Its nice to see the Philippine Eagle... that's it...
Review: We went to Davao for a vacation and planned to include the PEC on our last day itinerary.  It is easily accessible from downtown Davao. Just go to the Annil Bus Terminal located at the corner of San Pedro and Quirino Streets. The fare for air-conditioned bus from Davao City to Calinan is 45 pesos. Upon arriving at the Calinan Bus Terminal, there are tricycles waiting which goes directly to the Philippine Eagle Center (10 pesos fare per person if sharing the ride with other passengers). The total travel time is about an hour, shorter time if you travel by car.  We checked the website of PEC prior to our visit, where it is indicated that there are tour guides who will assist you for free. Upon paying for our entrance tickets, we saw a group of tour guides sitting at a table merrily chatting and ignoring us even if its obvious that we were there as local tourists. Then a group of foreigners arrived, and they eagerly approached and volunteered to tour the foreign guests around. ITS A COMPLETE SHAME THAT THESE TOUR GUIDES ARE DISCRIMINATING FELLOW FILIPINOS. -calling the attention of PEC Management.  We had no choice but to wander around on our own. The place is filled with lush vegetation, more like a jungle-type of atmosphere where you will see huge trees and wild flowers blooming. We had a glimpse of different bird and animal species aside from the Philippine Eagle. Its too bad that the famous eagle named "Pag-asa" is in a huge cage located on the upper part of the center and is currently not accessible due to some maintenance on-going.   Be careful while walking around because there are small insects which flies directly to your eyes, I got about four of them and my companion had three stuck in our eyes. Carefully pick them out as you might end up having pieces of these insects in your eyes if you just scratch your eyes with the insect in it. Better to wear your eyeglasses or shades or perhaps swimming goggles for kids ;-) it looks dumb but its better than having your visit ruined by insects stucked in your eyes.  There's a free toilet located near the ticket counter, along with the PEC souvenir shop and snack center.   Overall, the Philippine Eagle Center is worth a visit to see the Philippine's famous eagle.   IMPORTANT REMINDER: There's a man selling "driftwood" carving of the holy family outside the Center. It looks good and he explained to us that its worth the 1,200 pesos price tag because its an authentic wood carving from the nearby penal colony. We haggled for 600 pesos but ended up paying 700 pesos. Upon returning to Manila, we found out that the outer frame is genuine driftwood, but the sculpture itself is just molded from plaster of paris. Another shameful act of dishonesty from fellow Filipinos. :-(  The gift shops lined up outside the PEC sells more expensive goods. Better save your money and proceed to Aldevinco Shopping Center in downtown Davao. I bought batik shawls there for 180 pesos and you can get better design and quality from Aldevinco for as low as 150 pesos.

Review Title: A good spot to enjoy nature
Review: The Philippine Eagle Centre is one of the best tourist spots in Davao City even before when I was young. It houses the great Monkey-eating eagle which is arguably one of the largest eagles in the world.   However, there are some noticeable changes that needs immediate attention for further improvement of the area. 1. the cleanliness - the area must be kept clean at all times. Since most of the tourists there are nature-tripping, they really cannot appreciate litter. Garbage bins were full and there were some areas were very untidy.  2. price increase - the adult / child entrance fees of 100 / 50 would in my opinion, discourage local tourists to visit because it is somewhat costly. However, if the fee would benefit the animals in the centre then I may agree to the agree to the price increase (effective June 4, 2014) 3. predicament of the animals - As I have observed some cages of the animals lacked maintenance like cleaning, and pruning the weeds that engulfed the big cages. Maybe they should at least clean it once in a while.  If these three would be addressed, I think the centre will still be a great tourist icon in Davao City for many years to come. PLEASE DO ADDRESS THE ISSUES I HAVE RAISE. Not for me, but for the benefit of the next generation.   Tip: Look for handlers around the center that would provide opportunities for you to have a closer picture or even hold the eagles.

As someone who advocates life, I am thankful for this institution's endeavor to protect the Philippine eagle. However, as someone who's been to other aviaries, I would say that this place needs a lot of improvement. Well, considering the cheap entrance fee, I can see why the state of the park is like so, but if it's to protect this endangered species and to promote awareness about it, I would be willing to pay more just to uplift this aviary.  In terms of the flora, it is very abundant, and it also includes some other fauna that is endemic in the country. I also like how there are informative boards and trivia about different sub- species of eagles. I like how they are focused more on what's endemic in the country as well.  There are things that need improvement. For one, the museum's displays are obviously not taken care of properly. The stuffed animals have collected dust and some have been stored away probably because the environment in the museum is not controlled. Another thing is that the birds are chained. I know that this is to prevent the people from getting hurt, but another thing that can be done I think is to put a glass walkway or a cage walkway for people so that they can observe the birds fly freely. Some parts of the aviary specifically the wires are also not maintained. From the people I was with who've been there before, they also noted a considerably fewer number of birds. I think there is lack of funding in terms of breeding these birds and probably the lack of zookeepers.  To end, the place is worth a visit to get to know these endemic eagles more. It will help them raise funds to protect these animals as well as to repopulate them. However, don't expect an ideal aviary seeing as it needs further improvement. There are stalls for donations though, so hopefully many will be able to help.

Review Title: Up Close and Personal with Eagles!
Review: Aside from Pag-asa, you get to see different species of eagles, a giant yellow snake (right in the entrance), monkeys, wild boar, crocodile, and deer. The Philippine Eagle Center lies about an hours drive outside Davao City proper. The purpose of this institution is multifaceted but its main thrust seems to be educational; visitors will not only see the Philippine national bird up close but several other raptors endemic to the archipelago. The tour guide will emphasize the loss of natural habitat as well as hunting in the decline of these magnificent creatures. The center also offers "Keeper Talks" where the caretakers of specific species of eagles give more detailed presentations of their wards; unfortunately we did not make it to any of these talks and took only the general tour.  The Center cares for injured raptors, conducts field research, and engages in breeding programs.  There was a pond with an estuarine crocodile wallowing in the water. Another area featured Philippine macaques. Our guide pointed out a far-off tree where fruit bats were roosting.  It was both inspiring and depressing to encounter the eagles under these conditions. Most of the cages were small and even the largest enclosures would not have let the eagles do more than perhaps glide a short distance. We never witnessed any eagle fly. Some eagles were wounded and were no longer able to fly; they would not have survived in the wild anyway. One can only hope that the work they do does help preserve the Philippine Eagle and its other brethren.   In addition to the Philippine Eagle, we also saw Grass owls, White-bellied sea eagles, Brahminy Kites, Philippine serpent eagles and the Philippine eagle-hawk or Pinsker's Hawk.  One reviewer mentioned the leaves, twigs, and slippery walkways. Understand that the Center is in a tropical rain forest and the forest canopy is constantly shedding material which drops to the ground to either become fodder for animals or turn into topsoil. Perhaps the staff could sweep more frequently but totally clean paths may be too much to expect. It is a rain forest so the paths will be slippery; in fact our visit was interrupted by heavy rain showers. I do agree, however, that the signage needs updating. I am not sure how accessible the Eagle Center would for guests using wheelchairs; certainly some of the paths would seem to be extremely difficult to negotiate in a wheelchair. I would like to see larger bird enclosures - perhaps extensive netting covering several trees - for those raptors that were still capable of flight. I can only imagine what ii must look like to see one of them soar overhead.  The visit is worth the entrance price and the effort to go there. Be prepared for a jungle walk; this is not a sanitized zoo environment. Consider bringing binoculars to get a closer look at some of the eagles in their enclosures, though this is not absolutely needed. Ask the staff and guides for specific actions you can take as individuals to help make the survival of these eagles more likely.
